tha5:315: I, a monk, went to a charnel groundAnd saw a woman left there,Discarded in a cemetery,Full of worms that devoured her.
tha5:316: Some men were disgusted,Seeing her dead and rotten;But sexual desire arose in me,I was as if blind to her oozing body.
tha5:317: Quicker than the boiling of riceI left that place,Mindful and aware,I sat down to one side.
tha5:318: Then the realizationCame upon me —The danger became clear,And I was firmly repulsed.
tha5:319: Then my mind was liberated —See the excellence of the Dhamma!I’ve attained the three knowledges,And fulfilled the Buddha’s instructions.
tha5:320: If a person, wishing for a certain outcome,Applies themseves to a misguided endeavor,And they don’t achieve what they have practiced for,They say: "That’s a sign of my bad luck."
tha5:321: When a misfortune has been plucked out and conquered,To give it up in part would be like the losing throw of the dice;But to give up everything would be as if one was blind,Not discerning the even and the uneven.
tha5:322: You should only say what you would do;You shouldn’t say what you wouldn’t do.The wise will recognizeOne who talks without doing.
tha5:323: Just like a glorious flowerThat’s colourful but lacks fragrance;So is well-spoken speech fruitlessFor one not acting in accordance.
tha5:324: Just like a glorious flowerIs both colourful and fragrant,So is well-spoken speech fruitfulFor one who acts in accordance.
tha5:325: The sky rains, like a beautiful song,My little hut is roofed and pleasant,Sheltered from the wind,I dwell there peacefullySo rain, sky, if you wish.
tha5:326: The sky rains, like a beautiful song,My little hut is roofed and pleasant,Sheltered from the wind,I dwell there, with peaceful mind:So rain, sky, if you wish.
tha5:327: The sky rains, like a beautiful song,My little hut is roofed and pleasant,Sheltered from the wind,I dwell there, free of lust:So rain, sky, if you wish.
tha5:328: The sky rains, like a beautiful song,My little hut is roofed and pleasant,Sheltered from the wind,I dwell there, free of hate:So rain, sky, if you wish.
tha5:329: The sky rains, like a beautiful song,My little hut is roofed and pleasant,Sheltered from the wind,I dwell there, free of delusion:So rain, sky, if you wish.
tha5:330: My mentor helped me to learn,Hoping that I would practice those teachings;Aspiring for the deathless,I’ve done what was to be done.
tha5:331: I’ve arrived at the Dhamma,And witnessed it for myself, not based on hearsay.With purified knowledge, free of doubt,I declare it in your presence.
tha5:332: I know my past life;My divine eye is clarified;I’ve realized my own true goal,The Buddha’s instruction is fulfilled.
tha5:333: Being heedful in the training,I have learned your teachings well.All my defilements are ended;Now there is no more rebirth into any state of existence.
tha5:334: You advised me in noble ways;Compassionate, you helped teach me;Your instruction was not in vain —I, your student, am fully trained.
tha5:335: It was good, how my motherSpurred me onwards.When I heard her words,Advised by my mother,I became energetic, resolute —I realised supreme awakening.
tha5:336: I’m an Arahant, worthy of offerings,With the three knowledges and the vision of the deathless;I conquered Namuci’s army,And now I live without defilements.
tha5:337: The defilements which I had,Both internally and externally,Are now all cut off without remainder;They won’t arise again.
tha5:338: My skilful sistersaid this to me:"Now neither you nor IHave any entanglements."
tha5:339: Suffering is at an end;This is the last bodyTo transmigrate through birth and death:Now there is no more rebirth into any state of existence.
tha5:340: It was truly for my benefitThat the Buddha went to the river Nerañjara;When I heard his teaching,I rejected wrong view.
tha5:341: Previously, I performed the higher and lower sacrifices;I worshipped the sacred flame,Thinking, "This is purity."I was a blind, unenlightened person.
tha5:342: Caught in the thicket of wrong view,Deluded by misapprehension;Thinking impurity was purity,I was blind and ignorant.
tha5:343: I’ve abandoned wrong view,Rebirth into any state of existence is torn apart,I worship what is truly worthy of offerings:I bow to the Tathāgata.
tha5:344: I’ve abandoned all delusionRebirth into any state of existence is torn apart,Transmigration through births is finished,Now there is no more rebirth into any state of existence.
tha5:345: Three times a day —Morning, midday, and evening —I went down into the water at Gayā,For the Gayā spring festival.
tha5:346: "Whatever bad things I’ve doneIn previous births,I’ll now wash away right here" —This is the view I previously held.
tha5:347: Having heard the well-spoken wordsRegarding the Dhamma and the goal,I wisely reflectedOn the true, essential goal.
tha5:348: I’ve washed away all bad thingsI’m stainless, cleansed, pristine;The pure heir of the pure one,A rightful son of the Buddha.
tha5:349: When I plunged into the eight-fold stream,All bad things were washed away.I’ve attained the three knowledges,And fulfilled the Buddha’s instructions.
tha5:350: "Struck by a wind ailment,While staying in a forest grove;You’ve gone into a tough place for gathering alms:How will you get by, monk?"
tha5:351: "Pervading my bodyWith lots of rapture and happiness,Putting up with what’s tough,I’ll dwell in the forest.
tha5:352: Developing the establishments of mindfulness,The faculties and the powers,Developing the factors of awakening,I’ll dwell in the forest.
tha5:353: Having seen those who are energetic, resolute,Always of strong effort,Harmonious and serene,I’ll dwell in the forest.
tha5:354: Recollecting the BuddhaThe highest, the tamed, who hassamādhiNot lazy by day or by nightI’ll dwell in the forest."
tha5:355: I’ll cage you, mind,Like an elephant in a stockade.Born of the flesh, that net of sensual pleasures,I won’t urge you to do bad.
tha5:356: Caged, you won’t escape,Like an elephant who can’t find an open gate.Demon-mind, you won’t wander again and again,Bullying, and loving to do bad.
tha5:357: Just as a strong trainer with a hook,Takes a wild, newly captured elephantAnd wins it over against its will,So I’ll win you over.
tha5:358: Just as a fine charioteer, skilled in the tamingOf fine horses, tames a thoroughbred,So I’ll tame you,Firmly established in the five powers.
tha5:359: I’ll bind you with mindfulness,I’m committed to taming you;Restrained by harnessed energy,Mind, you won’t go far from here.
tha5:360: With fault-finding mind, the dullardListens to the conqueror’s teaching.They’re as far from true Dhamma,As the earth is from the sky.
tha5:361: With fault-finding mind, the dullardListens to the conqueror’s teaching.They decline in the true Dhamma,Like the moon in the waning fortnight.
tha5:362: With fault-finding mind, the dullardListens to the conqueror’s teaching.They wither away in the true Dhamma,Like a fish in too little water.
tha5:363: With fault-finding mind, the dullardListens to the conqueror’s teaching.They don’t thrive in the true Dhamma,Like a rotten seed in a field.
tha5:364: But one with contended mindWho listens to the conqueror’s teachings —Having ended all defilements,Having witnessed the unshakable,Having arrived at the highest peace —They realizenibbānawithout defilements.
tha5:365: I’ve received full ordination,I am liberated, without defilements,I’ve seen the Blessed One myself,And even stayed together with him.
tha5:366: The Blessed One, the teacher,Spent much of the night in the open;Then he, who is so skilled at dwelling in meditation,Entered his dwelling.
tha5:367: Spreading out his outer robe,Gotama made his bed;Like a lion in a rocky cave,With fear and dread abandoned.
tha5:368: Then, with lovely enunciation,Soṇa, a disciple of the Buddha,Recited the true DhammaIn the presence of the best of Buddhas.
tha5:369: When he has fully understood the five aggregates,Developed the straight path,And arrived at the highest peace,He will realizenibbānawithout defilements.
tha5:370: Whatever wise person, understanding their teacher’s words,Stays with them, their affection growing;That wise person is indeed devoted —Knowing about Dhammas, they’re distinguished.
tha5:371: When extreme stresses arise,Whoever does not tremble, but reflects instead,That wise person is indeed strong —Knowing about Dhammas, they’re distinguished.
tha5:372: Steady as the ocean, imperturbable,Their wisdom is deep, and they see the subtle goal;That wise person is indeed immovable —Knowing about Dhammas, they’re distinguished.
tha5:373: They’re very learned, and have memorized the Dhamma,practising Dhamma in accordance with Dhamma;That wise person is indeed such —Knowing about Dhammas, they’re distinguished.
tha5:374: They know the meaning of what is said,And having known, they act appropriately;That wise person is indeed one who has mastered the meaning —Knowing about Dhammas, they’re distinguished.
